Award.AwardTitle: Developing teachers as computational thinkers through supported authentic experiences in computing modeling and simulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This project addresses the need for a computationally-enabled STEM workforce by equipping teachers with the skills necessary to prepare students for future endeavors as computationally-enabled scientists and citizens, and by investigating the most effective ways to provide this instruction to teachers. The project also addresses the immediate challenge presented by the Next Generation Science Standards to prepare middle school science teachers to implement rich computational thinking (CT) experiences, such as the use, creation and analysis of computer models and simulations, within science classes.

The project, a partnership between the Santa Fe Institute and the Santa Fe Public School District, directly addresses middle school teachers' understanding, practice, and teaching of modern scientific practice. Using the Project GUTS program and professional development model as a foundation, this project will design and develop a set of Resources, Models, and Tools (RMTs) that collectively form the basis for a comprehensive professional development (PD) program, then study teachers' experiences with the RMTs and assess how well the RMTs prepared teachers to implement the curriculum. The PD program includes: an online PD network; workshops; webinars and conferences; practicum and facilitator support; and curricular and program guides. The overall approach to the project is design based implementation research (DBIR). Methods used for the implementation research includes: unobtrusive measures such as self-assessment sliders and web analytics; the knowledge and skills survey (KS-CT); interviews (teachers and the facilitators); analysis of teacher modified and created models; and observations of practicum and classroom implementations. Data collection and analysis in the implementation research serve two purposes: a) design refinement and b) case study development. The implementation research employs a mixed-method, nonequivalent group design with embedded case studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developing teachers as computational thinkers through supported authentic experiences in computer modeling and simulation (aka "Teachers with GUTS") is a design based implementation research project that engaged researchers from the MIT STEP Lab and district partners and teachers in Santa Fe, Albuquerque and Las Cruces, New Mexico and Richmond, Virginia to implement, study, and refine a set of resources, models, and tools for the teaching of computational thinking (CT) in the context of computer modeling and simulation within science classrooms. The year long professional development (PD) program included a summer intensive workshop, a practicum experience, quarterly workshops, monthly webinars, and interaction on an online PD network that served as the hub for the community of practice. Additional implementation support included curricular guides and real-time facilitator support. The methods used in the implementation research included a pre-/post-survey of knowledge and skills survey (KS-CT); interviews (teachers and facilitators); analysis of teacher modified and created models; and observations of classroom implementations. Analysis of the data informed the refinement of the curricular materials and professional development program, and served as the basis for teacher case studies. 

Intellectual Merit. 

This project addresses the need for a computationally-enabled STEM workforce by equipping teachers with the skills necessary to prepare students for future endeavors as computationally-enabled scientists and citizens. Teachers with GUTS PD program increased middle school science teachers' knowledge and skills in computational thinking and their self-efficacy. The PD program also prepared middle school teachers to implement the use-modify-create progression, a pedagogical strategy that has been seen to engage students in progressively deeper CT. Students showed increases of CT knowledge and skills from pre- to post- survey administration. Student outcomes support a dosage response relationship between the number of curricular units a student experienced and gains in knowledge and skills in CT.

We found that teachers' enactments of the Project GUTS curriculum were linked to their epistemic beliefs about the value of computer modeling and simulation in the science classroom. Teachers who believed the value was in exposing students to computer science tended to enact the curriculum focusing on building models. Teachers who thought the value was in leveraging computer models for scientific inquiry tended to focus on running experiments using computer models as experimental testbeds. Teachers who saw the value as exposing computer simulations as scientific models tended to enact the curriculum focusing on uncovering the abstractions in models, and whether the abstractions reflected what students understood about science or not. 

Though positive gains were seen in teachers' knowledge and skills in CT, implementation of the curriculum was uneven. Analysis of the relationship between teachers' enactments of the curriculum and their CT knowledge and skills uncovered that a few teachers who had gained CT knowledge and skills and had experienced success in modifying and creating computer models chose not to implement the curriculum, and surprisingly, some teachers with minimal levels of CS knowledge and skills were able to implement the curriculum by focusing on abstraction in models rather than on programming to construct or revise models. We identified several factors that may have contributed to these outcomes. A belief that their students lacked the capability for higher-order thinking (analysis and creation of models) limited teachers' implementation of the curriculum regardless of their own capacity for CT. Additionally, a teacher's focus on "reading and decoding" models to assesses whether or not a model was realistic (based on students' knowledge base) or valid scientifically (based on what the model included and left out, and the data it produced) uncovered a productive avenue to engage students in CT without teaching programming. 

Broader impacts: 

The project had a significant impact on workforce development in New Mexico, Virginia and across the Nation. Over 170 teachers participated in PD workshops offered by this project and its partners. The project's evaluation determined that the program can serve as a model for preparing teachers to offer students instruction in modern scientific practice. 

The project developed the TeacherswithGUTS.org online PD network that serves as an institutional and community portal through which educators can contribute and find CT resources, discuss curricular and pedagogical topics, practice skill building, and sustain their interest in integrating CT in science classrooms. In addition to producing refined and tested resources, models, and tools, the project also contributes a validated assessment instrument to measure students' and teachers' CT knowledge and skills in the context of computer modeling and simulation.

The finding that teachers with limited CS skills can implement the curriculum through a focus on decoding abstractions in models led to the development of a new theory of how CT and computer modeling and simulation practices can be integrated in science classrooms. This theory became the catalyst for three new STEM+C projects that investigate the promise of a "decoding" models approach.
